keyTakeAways: A man, Billy Joe Cagle, was arrested at Atlanta's Hartsfield-Jackson International Airport after his family alerted authorities that he was planning to shoot up the airport on a social media livestream.
Cagle, a 49-year-old convicted felon from Cartersville, Georgia, was found with an AR-15 assault rifle and 27 rounds of ammunition in a Chevrolet pickup truck parked outside the airport terminal.
The incident was averted due to early intervention by family members who recognized dangerous behavior and reported it to law enforcement.
Cagle had posted on Facebook claiming to suffer from schizophrenia and said he was taking medication, but still expressed intent to harm people at the airport.
He was charged with making terroristic threats, criminal attempt to commit aggravated assault, possession of a firearm during the commission of a felony, and possession of a firearm by a felon.
Atlanta police and federal authorities are investigating how Cagle obtained the firearm, which law enforcement states he was not legally allowed to possess.
The incident underscores the importance of community vigilance, social media monitoring, and early reporting of potential threats.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Billy Joe Cagle, a 49-year-old convicted felon from Cartersville, Georgia, was arrested at Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport after his family reported that he had streamed on social media a plan to 'shoot it up' at the airport. Officers found an AR-15 rifle and 27 rounds of ammunition in his Chevrolet pickup truck parked outside the terminal. Cagle had previously posted on Facebook about his schizophrenia and medication, but expressed intent to harm people. Thanks to early family reporting and coordinated law enforcement action, a potential mass shooting was averted. Cagle has been charged with multiple firearm and terroristic threats related to the incident. The case highlights the role of community awareness, social media monitoring, and rapid response in preventing public tragedies.
title: Man Arrested at Atlanta Airport After Social Media Threat to Shoot Up Terminal
